website_summaries.verdict: Whether you need freshly ground beans at home or while traveling, this quality coffee grinder provides a uniform grind for every cup.
pros: This grinder is sturdy, stable, and screws on top of a standard Mason jar
Takes only a couple minutes to grind enough beans for 2 cups
Quieter than an electric grinder, and easier to clean
Can also be used to grind spices
cons: Needs trial and error to determine correct grind size
Not large enough to grind beans for more than about 2 cups at a time

website_summaries.verdict: This manual Japanese-made grinder is great for espresso, but if you're looking for a coarse grind, you may want to look elsewhere.
pros: Strong grind shaft and burr stabilization plate for uniform grind
Ceramic conical burrs for a precise, uniform grind
cons: Great for fine powders but not as good for coarser grinds

customer_reviews.title: Beware of clones
customer_reviews.text: It's a long story why I have two hand grinders. One is a real Hario. The other is a copy. One works, one doesn't. They're both identical except the ceramic grinder. The Hario that's grey works great. The clone that's white can't even grind - it'll only crush. If you get one with the white ceramic, get rid of it.
customer_reviews.author: PatC

customer_reviews.title: like most of the reviewers
customer_reviews.text: I purchased this coffee grinder January 2018. At first, like most of the reviewers , I thought it was great. Now, after the fourth cleaning and reassembly, not so much. The grind adjustment screw loosens during grinding now unless I tighten to the point of very fine as for espresso. I use the pour over which requires a medium grind but, the screw loosens and the grind has chunks. I have to constantly adjust during grinding. I do not recommend this product.
customer_reviews.author: Kindle Customer

customer_reviews.title: The “stabilizer plate” does nothing
customer_reviews.text: I bought the “plus” because of the claims of the added stabilizer plate that is suppose to stabilize the burr and make it more consistent especially with more coarse grinds. After receiving it I was disappointed. The hole in the stabilizer plate is way too big to actually offer any benefit and the burr rocks back and forth making very inconsistent grinds. I attached two photos where you can see how much the rod can move within the stabilizer plate. I wouldn’t have been upset since the price isn’t very high but frustrating considering it is marketed as improved.
customer_reviews.author: Jacob

customer_reviews.title: Love this grinder!
customer_reviews.text: After much research I decided to purchase the Hario Skerton Pro and I am very happy with it. It cost more than the other versions Hario produces but corrects the problems that customers complained they had. It is very easy to use, easy to clean and easy to adjust the grinder. I am enjoying the ritual of grinding every morning.
customer_reviews.author: Del

customer_reviews.title: The zen of grinding coffee
customer_reviews.text: Initially bought this as a temporary use item to replace my electric burr grinder that had died, until moving in with my SO, since he also has an electric burr grinder. Since using this, we've decided it does a better job than his, which is also getting old. I think the ceramic heads will last a lot longer, and it's kind of a zen thing now to come home after a crappy work day and just grind some coffee.
customer_reviews.author: psfollett

customer_reviews.title: Good grind, FOREVER to grind it though
customer_reviews.text: Grind is near perfect, but you will spend what seems like HOURS cranking that shaft to get those grinds. It's more trouble than it's worth, and I wish I'd spent the money and upgraded to a better electric grinder. If you want to grind enough for a pot of drip coffee, you'll spend over 10 minutes cranking it. For espresso, I just spend a solid 3 minutes to get enough grinds for my stove top espresso pot. More trouble than it's worth, at least for me. It's now a novelty item and for emergency use.
customer_reviews.author: Mr. Roboto

customer_reviews.title: Inconsistent Grind
customer_reviews.text: This grinder produces an inconsistent grind coarseness no matter what you do. Ive tried holding the grinder by my chest, putting the grinder flat and even using a slow moving drill for a consistent speed. The grind coarseness ranges from fine to large which you can see in the photos I've attached.
customer_reviews.author: David  W

customer_reviews.title: Over time, not what I expected.
customer_reviews.text: Initially I gave this coffee grinder 5 stars; it was a big improvement over the previous model. What I noticed, however, eventually, was that after grinding just enough fo 1-2 cups of coffee, the screw mechanism adjusting the grind size changed, got looser. Instead of a medium grind, which I usually did, I started getting coarse grinds. So, I had to readjust the grind mechanism screw prior to grinding. Not a big chore but it shouldn't happen. When properly adjusted, the grind remains uniform for one cup.
customer_reviews.author: SMB 69

customer_reviews.title: Great grinder with a simple modification to power grinding
customer_reviews.text: I grind to a fine "near espresso" grind and the Hario Skerton does a perfect job. I replaced the handle with a M6X1 pitch Right hand Thread Long Rod Coupling HeXNut and use a nut driver on my cordless electric drill to power the grind process more quickly and with less effort. I find the combination of the Hario Grinder and the drill drive a perfect low cost solution to great fresh ground coffee at minimum cost. I love the Hario Skerton grinder.
customer_reviews.author: druckle

customer_reviews.title: Made in China, not Japan
customer_reviews.text: Like? • Glass bowl so ground coffee grind and level easily visible. Dislike? • Too 'fat.' Hard to grasp and provide leverage during grinding. • Crank design coupled with thick body makes it difficult and tiring to grind more than a few grams of coffee. • Perhaps it is a Chinese mill and Japanese glass, but the fit was poor and difficult to start threading the mill body onto the glass receiver. • I've attached an image scanned from the instruction manual. The item description touts the Japanese origin; however, only the glass part is made in Japan. The rest of the mill, including the grinder, is made in China.
customer_reviews.author: Dr. Andy W.

customer_reviews.title: Tried a crappy krups bur grinder that somehow has 1k+ positive reviews ...
customer_reviews.text: A bodum bistro bur grinder served me wel for years. Tried a crappy krups bur grinder that somehow has 1k+ positive reviews on here?? That had static cling and powder all over every use. So I decided to go prehistoric, all mechanical. I only use a very course setting since I use an aeropress. This delivered better then electric. It does take about 30 seconds to get a cup of coffee. All the parts are sturdy.
customer_reviews.author: Torrentula81

customer_reviews.title: Pretty good grinder but a bit of a pain to clean
customer_reviews.text: This grinder is great for us since I am the only one in the household that drinks coffee. The coarseness settings are good and I appreciate the clear plastic top so you can see the progress and adjust the beans if needed. That being said, after each use, we wash it by taking it apart and setting it upside down on a wire rack to dry. The inside (part that actually grinds the beans) has worn down over time and I'm worried it will not fully clean despite doing a pretty thorough job. Will update this review in the future if that turns out to be the case. For now, it's doing its job well enough.
customer_reviews.author: Luyou Sun

customer_reviews.title: Great grinder, good value
customer_reviews.text: Great quality grinder. It makes anything from French press grind down to near flour size grind for espresso with no issues. Takes a while to grind beans but no longer than any other manual grinder and it holds enough for several servings. I did have the tensioning screw that sets the grind backing off a notch or two after several dozen grinding sessions but overall it’s a non issue, I now just check it every time I refill my beans. It’s a little large for traveling but sits on my counter and takes up less space than my old electric grinder.
customer_reviews.author: Customer

customer_reviews.title: Amazing compact grinder
customer_reviews.text: I had typically not paid much attention to using fresh ground beans and how wrong was I!! Once I realized that, and given that I wanted something quiet and compact, there was nothing better than Hario in the market. It has a great following for a reason and I could see why with the ease and precision that I experienced. I would highly recommend it! Note : setting is more hit and trial but there are charts online that you can use. I make a French press or pour over for 11-12 clicks with screw starting at the very bottom worked great for me
customer_reviews.author: RK

customer_reviews.title: I bought this unit because I wanted to grind more coffee more easily, mainly for French press and cold brew
customer_reviews.text: I've had Hario's Mini Mill for about 3 years now, which I use regularly. I bought this unit because I wanted to grind more coffee more easily, mainly for French press and cold brew. I am actually pretty disappointed that the conical burr grinder on this unit moves laterally very easily, so much so that it contacts the stationary burr, while leaving a huge gap on the other side. Without getting something to stabilize the movable conical burr, you will not make a consistent coarse grind with this unit, and you will probably wear down the burrs faster than you were hoping. Yes, this unit is larger than the Mini Mill, but it is not as well-made.
customer_reviews.author: Alice in Dallas

customer_reviews.title: Great for Daily Coffee Preparation
customer_reviews.text: This product is a high quality, easy to use adjustable burr grinder, which coffee expects recommend over blade grinders. Additionally, the jar seems to hold about just enough for the daily brewing task, which is also recommended for better coffee. I found that an earlier reviewer's recommendation to replace the circular nut and crank with a hex nut and nut driller attachment with power drill is highly praiseworthy. Note that I do use a smaller drill at lower speeds. Pros - well made, reasonable price, standard canning jar for replacement, uniform grinding and relatively easy to use. Cons - slow grind process by hand, hard to fully clean the burr grinding part and notably more costly than cheap mark-offs.
customer_reviews.author: David G

customer_reviews.title: Works very well
customer_reviews.text: I've had it for about a month now, and it works great. I had been using a Javapress one previously, which worked fine but had some things about which were kinky or frustrating. This grinder is easy to load whole beans into, much easier to grip and since the base screws into the top it doesn't occasionally dump ground coffee all over the ground (also: I'm clumsy). If you don't mind hand grinding, prefer hand grinding, or want to take it on the road in a trailer or something, it's a great grinder for that. If space was an issue (like backpacking) I'd say the Javapress might be preferable just bc it's very slim and compact.
customer_reviews.author: Texafornian

customer_reviews.title: Awesome Manual Coffee Grinder!
customer_reviews.text: I love this thing! Conical Burr Grinders are usually pretty pricey but this manual grinder makes a perfect grind for all kinds of coffee while still being affordable. You can manually adjust the grind size from fine grinds for drip/pour over to a coarser ground for french press! And this thing is small enough for travel! It will easily fit in a suitcase, carry on, backpack, or even a purse! It also has a screw on lid for the bottom part where the grind goes. It is the perfect size for my wife and my daily coffee. I 100% recommend this product!
customer_reviews.author: MikeZ

customer_reviews.title: Winner for the price
customer_reviews.text: My husband loves this! You can grind more than 1 cup and the action of the actual grind is easy even for me. I was nervous bc most of this price range are not great quality but we are happy. We've been only using it for a few week so not sure on durability yet. But coffee grinds also don't get everywhere. Clean transfer of grinds to the coffee pot. I like that the container is glass. I did a lot of research due to not being able to afford a $100+ and I think it's a winner for the price for sure!
customer_reviews.author: Mills

customer_reviews.title: Very decent hand grinder
customer_reviews.text: It's a very good hand grinder. Dialing it in is straight forward and after nearly two months of use I haven't had any real issues. The grind is as uniform as you can ask of such a cheap grinder. In conclusion, if you don't mind putting in the effort to grind you're own coffee beans then this is pretty much as cheap as you should go.
customer_reviews.author: Phil Paskal

customer_reviews.title: Solid Coffee Grinder
customer_reviews.text: Works really well! I had read some people saying the hex part of the shaft where the handle slips on had stripped... How on earth they managed to do that I have no idea. Just turn the handle nice and smoothly, it doesn't take a lot of force or effort. Grind size seems pretty consistent. The only thing is the grind size adjustment doesn't have any type of marking so if you want 2 different sizes of grind for different types of coffee making (say, pour-over and french press) you need to make sure you remember which one you used last and how many clicks you adjust it from there. Not a big deal though.
customer_reviews.author: Dana

customer_reviews.title: Look elsewhere
customer_reviews.text: The quality of the plastic and metal parts seem very sturdy and well built. The ceramic conical burr leaves much to be desired. It seems the hole in the “center” of the cone is not actually in the center and produces horribly inconsistent grinds. When adjusted much coarser than a French press grind (which you would never use), with no beans, the ceramic parts rub each other. Perhaps I got a bad unit, but I feel like I just threw $50 in the trash. I have a mini porlex that isn’t a life changing grinder by any means, but it’s much better than this.
customer_reviews.author: steven k.

customer_reviews.title: A lesson in patience
customer_reviews.text: Ssssssslllooooooooowwwwwwwww! If you're looking to make your morning coffee a laborious pain in the a@#, this is the grinder for you. If you need to learn patience and want to seek zen through patient suffering, this is your coffee grinder. If your forearms and biceps are withered and girlie and you want to get ripped while grinding coffee, again, this would be a good choice. Not or folks that want to grind up some bean, brew it and go.
customer_reviews.author: BCSAlaska

customer_reviews.title: Great Grinder
customer_reviews.text: I got this for my son in law as a gift from his Amazon wish list. I was visiting about a week ago. He said he really likes it. I got up and used it. It was a bit tiring for me but it did an excellent job on the grind of the coffee bean. My daughter & son in law have 7 kids so it's great for the kids grinding coffee for daddy. They love it, too! I'll order one for myself, and this same brand, if they make an electric one.
customer_reviews.author: M Kathy King

customer_reviews.title: Not worth the extra $$$, kinda junky for the the price.
customer_reviews.text: Could be built better than the models that are cheaper Hario brand. It’s causing my usual coffee to extract different ( to be expected with a bur grinder) unfortunately, it’s imparting an off tasting flavor no matter how I’ve adjusted the grind setting. While it looks like quality, its not too different from previous models. It’s got an updated look and parts that will fail after daily use for a year. I can already seen wearing marks due to the loose fit where the crank arm attaches to the drive point for the grinder. This is was discovered after the 4th attempt to dial in the grind on the same bag of coffee.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Good, but takes a long time and handle loosens over time.
customer_reviews.text: The good: It works as published, in that it grinds the coffee consistently. The burr is easy to adjust. I would say this is what I had in mind when I wanted a manual grinder. I would say it's perfect for travel or camping where you don't have access to power. The not so good: I found that it took a long time to grind enough bean for a cup of coffee, and it was a bit loud, and since I bought it for my cubicle in an office environment, I didn't feel great about making that much noise every morning and probably annoying my coworkers. I eventually abandoned this grinder.
customer_reviews.author: David

customer_reviews.title: Nifty little coffee grinder
customer_reviews.text: Perfect for an individual or a couple. Grinding enough beans to make a cup of coffee takes less than a minute and it's nice that I don't have to plug it in (I can grind while I check the birds out on the feeder outside the window). It looks nice enough to leave out on the counter and it's convenient to be able to keep any unused grounds right in the container you ground them into. It's easy to adjust the grind settings as well. I have used this everyday for ~6 months now and it was definitely worth the purchase.
customer_reviews.author: MK

customer_reviews.title: Not up to Hario's usual standards
customer_reviews.text: Good: It grinds coffee. Bad: It gets jammed. Coarser grinds are uneven. What is most frustrating about this is that there's nothing stabilizing the shaft from the crank to the burrs. This means any pressure to the side while grinding will move the burrs back and forth, making the grind uneven. They'll sell you an "upgrade kit" that stabilizes it, or you can buy a more expensive model. It isn't an upgrade, it's adding in a piece that should've been there in the first place. I'd give this 3/5 stars, but they've also raised the price about $10 since I bought mine.
customer_reviews.author: HappyProgFan

customer_reviews.title: Great value for your money. Highly recommend
customer_reviews.text: The courser you grind the more drastick the size variation becomes. I use it with my flair espresso maker and thats a GREAT entry level set up on a budget. All round this is a great grinder. Best used for espresso or drip. Will note, it doesnt take forever once you get it down, but you definitely want to have patience with grinding for multiple people *UPDATE* Still love this grinder. The bit at the top fits a 9/32 socket if anyone else wants to use a drill. Definitely recommend
customer_reviews.author: Nick

customer_reviews.title: Sit and hold the jar between your legs for easier grinding
customer_reviews.text: Works well for me. The hardest part is holding the jar while turning the handle, but I discovered something very simple that makes it much easier. Sit in a chair and hold the base of the grinder between your legs (I've only tried this while wearing jeans). The rubber piece that fits around the glass will hold the glass jar very firmly so you can put your energy into turning the handle instead of trying to hold the jar.
customer_reviews.author: Chuck

customer_reviews.title: Great for the grind
customer_reviews.text: This is a very durable product. I have had it for several years and it always grinds my coffee beans. The jar cna be sealed to keep your coffee grounds fresh. The rubber lid to keep th ebeans in the hopper when grinding does become a little sticky with time and needs to be washed to keep it from feeling gummy. It helps that it is entirely mechanical without any electronic parts, although this can be inconvenient when you are late in the mornings, just want a cup of coffee, and don't have any ready to go coffee grounds.
customer_reviews.author: George Chen

customer_reviews.title: Not worth the hassle
customer_reviews.text: The two things my husband and I dislike most about this grinder are 1) It takes so long to grind your coffee! It takes me at least 5 minutes to grind only enough coffee for two servings. We grind our coffee fresh every morning, so this is not a fun task to wake up to. 2) It’s so complicated to change the grind setting to make the grounds coarser or finer. There are too many little parts to remove and put back together. We finally bit the bullet and paid $70 for the Handground Manual Grinder. 10 times easier and worth every penny.
customer_reviews.author: Anna Nevienski

customer_reviews.title: It works, I guess
customer_reviews.text: I was expecting some level of effort with a hand grinder, but nearly 10 minutes to grind 60g of coffee makes this just about pointless. There are far better electric grinders for not much more of an investment.
customer_reviews.author: caerus

customer_reviews.title: A High-Quality, Low-Tech Grinder
customer_reviews.text: This grinder is perfect for people who like to enjoy the ritual of a well-prepared cup of coffee. I had been looking for a manual coffee grinder for some time. I don't drink coffee that often, and I preferred manual operation to avoid the hassle/noise of another corded appliance. I read some online reviews that gave this top marks, and I completely agree. It's easy to adjust for a coarse, French press grind. The consistency is also much more even than with blade style grinders. This grinder is perfect for people who like to enjoy the ritual of a well-prepared cup of coffee. Looking forward to many years with this product.
customer_reviews.author: Brian G. Cox

customer_reviews.title: ... get the whole pourover coffee setup and this was recommended by a knowledgable person who works at an artesinal ...
customer_reviews.text: I decided to get the whole pourover coffee setup and this was recommended by a knowledgable person who works at an artesinal coffee roasting establishment. However, the hand-grinding is just too much to do without coffee so I modified it. Found a Black and Decker cordless screwdriver also available on Amazonand replaced the nut and handle with two washers and an 11/16 nut. Then used the screwdriver, and adapter and an 11/16 socket to grind the coffee. So much faster! Be sure to clean the ceramic parts from time to time. Take it apart and brush gently to remove any particles from the grooves. If the grooves are clogged they aren't going to grind the coffee correctly.
customer_reviews.author: Martha L

customer_reviews.title: so good. It seems to grind the coffee well
customer_reviews.text: So far, so good. It seems to grind the coffee well, but the reason I'm giving it 4 stars is because the directions were a bit confusing with the metal piece that attaches the spindle. I just looked at the photo to figure it out. And, since it's manual, get ready for a workout. You might want to ask someone to help you, or take a break. Also, you can't choose the size of the grind, but so far, I've had no issues using this for cold brew and on a stovetop espresso. The coffee was ground well.
customer_reviews.author: Kimberly V

customer_reviews.title: Look no further...
customer_reviews.text: this grinder is all you need for a good grind. I've owned two and would buy a third if necessary. It can be a little tricky to find the perfect grind for your brewing method but once you do it's amazing. It's relatively easy to clean and very simple to use. It doesn't make a big mess or warm up your beans like electric grinders.
customer_reviews.author: Punky

customer_reviews.title: Coffee coffee where’s my coffee!
customer_reviews.text: The biggest issue I had with this is that the handle screw kept coming loose and I constantly had to readjust the tension for the grind size. The grinder itself worked well but don’t expect to get a lot of coffee ground quickly because it will literally take you several minutes of aggressive turning to get enough grounds for 1 cup of coffee.
customer_reviews.author: John Taylor

customer_reviews.title: At the finer settings, however
customer_reviews.text: The mill performs its basic function very well. The beans are ground consistently, according to the selected grade of fineness. No complaint there. At the finer settings, however, the crank is somewhat hard to turn. Grinding a full jar in one session is a good way to exercise your biceps. It would help if the jar was easier to hold on to. The supplied non-slip base is of little use. I find it easiest to hold the mill against the body and crank away. In ease of operation there is some room for improvement. All in all, though, highly recommended.
customer_reviews.author: H.R.

customer_reviews.title: GREAT product!
customer_reviews.text: Face it...old school hand grinding your coffee is kinda cool !!! Naaaaahhhh....it's really cool and I believe it tastes better. No scientific backing on my end...but it just is what it is. In regards to all the comments about getting a fake, I got the real deal in the Hario box. It truly is a great product and hand grinding your coffee is just so darn cool !! Well worth the price.
customer_reviews.author: durangoclimber

customer_reviews.title: QUALITY THROUGH AND THROUGH!  Japanese made=EXCELLENT
customer_reviews.text: Wow, I really love this thing. I did a lot of research before buying this one. THIS IS QUALITY MADE. The grinder doesn't have any cheap plastic parts like my previous grinder. It's got a hopper that can hold probably 10-12 tbsp of coffee beans. And it can also connect to a larger container like a Ball Mason Jar if you prefer. The included jar is plenty big to hold maybe 3 pots worth of coffee grounds (we make batches of 3-4 cups at a time). Don't presume I'll have to buy another grinder for a long time. I'll let you know - it's been for 5 months and it's served us very well through lots of uses.
customer_reviews.author: T. Brunson

customer_reviews.title: Guinuine Hario product!
customer_reviews.text: What I received is an authentic Hario product. I'm very pleased with the quality of this coffee mill. Years ago I had the original Hario mill and liked it quite a lot..... Eventually the burrs wore out and dull. The Hario Pro is a substantial improvement on the original. Well worth the little extra $! Don't know if the burrs will hold out any longer than the original but for the price.... You can't beat this mill for quality and consistency.
customer_reviews.author: Bumpkin

customer_reviews.title: The One
customer_reviews.text: This is it. I've had two (cheaper) cylinder grinders that both broke w/in six months of purchase from typical use. This one shows no signs of breaking in the ten months that I've had it. If it breaks it'll be my own fault - in which case I'll repurchase it.
customer_reviews.author: Andrew Smith

customer_reviews.title: Best coffee grinder ever.
customer_reviews.text: Bought this coffee grinder for our RV, and it's perfect! Compact, fits into the cupboard and quickly grinds beans for the perfect cup of coffee! So easy to use and really a game changer for a fresh cup in the morning.
customer_reviews.author: Mikey

customer_reviews.title: Fantastic coffee grinder!
customer_reviews.text: Let me start by saying that I purchased from Amazon, not third party seller. I received the genuine Hario Skerton, not a counterfeit. I absolutely love this grinder, it's easy to use. There are some really good YouTube videos explaining how to set up the grind. Also, the instructions are in English along with Japaneese. With tax, I spent just over $29 with Prime shipping for this coffee grinder. Finally, the parts are dishwasher safe per the instructions. Update: I've used this daily for one year. No issues. It is a workhorse.
customer_reviews.author: Chad

customer_reviews.title: Too difficult to grind.
customer_reviews.text: The end product of ground beans is fine, but the process of grinding is far too difficult. If you typically brew a few cups of coffee when you wake up, be prepared for a 10-minute intense arm workout every morning. Side note: I thought the product was made in Japan, but only the glass container part is. The rest of the parts are made in China.
customer_reviews.author: Lance

customer_reviews.title: Really hard to hold in place
customer_reviews.text: The quality of the grind is good. I like the adjustable ceramic grinder head. The mechanics and ergonomics of holding it while grinding is terrible. It doesn't stay stable. I can't give the grinder away because nobody wants to exert this amount of energy to make a cup of coffee. Making coffee for a group would take all morning. Maybe Hario could make a clamping base/cradle for this grinder to stabilize. I'm decently strong and this is a pain to use. The square base box style grinders are much easier to use because they are stable and easy to hold in place while grinding.
customer_reviews.author: Marcel Cooper

customer_reviews.title: Good grinder.
customer_reviews.text: I use this one at my office in conjunction with my Aeropress. Haven't noticed the loosening of the adjuster mentioned by some others so far. Pleased with the grind consistency. It's noisy, and you have to hold on tight, but it does the job when the $200 version isn't available.
customer_reviews.author: T B

customer_reviews.title: Not a good grinder !!!!!!!
customer_reviews.text: I thought this from reading reviews that it was so wonderful to grind drip coffee. Unfortunately It is the worst. Very uneven on grinding the beans. Way too many different variations are laughed large boulders small boulders and smaller which makes uneven extraction for your coffee. I wish they would take it back
customer_reviews.author: Gideon Baum

customer_reviews.title: Handle won't stay tight while grinding
customer_reviews.text: This grinder flexible top material clings to dust and coffee bean debris, making it hard to clean. The grinder doesn't do a very even job of grinding medium size pieces to use in a drip filter. The worst feature is that the handle loosens from its attachment point in just a few turns, making it useless for grinding until tightened, and it loosens again a few seconds later.
customer_reviews.author: Charles Preston

customer_reviews.title: A must have upgrade...buy it!
customer_reviews.text: I had the first generation which work well. This upgrade grinds 4 scoops of coffee, enough for 20 ounces of brewed coffee in 3.5 minutes and is a great improvement over earlier versions. The handle is stronger and due to the redesign of the interior coffee bean hold allows for quicker grinding. I had and tried from time to time an electric coffee bean grinder and always returned to the Hario. If you still do camping, this would also be the grinder of choice. Buy it!
customer_reviews.author: marshal

customer_reviews.title: Not Suitable For Espresso
customer_reviews.text: It's my fault for not looking in to this before purchasing, but this device is really not suitable for espresso, despite what the manual says. The grind adjustment on this thing is finicky at best, and micro-adjustments are simply not possible. For that matter, hitting a consistent grind twice in a row is also impossible, as the adjustment nut tends to loosen on its own and the way its seated doesn't give you much room for error in positioning it.
customer_reviews.author: Daniel McDonald

customer_reviews.title: "Stabilizer plate" is ineffective and poorly designed
customer_reviews.text: See the review of this product below to see pictures of what I'm talking about.  So it turns out that the burr shaft is about 1/4" diameter, and the stabilizer diameter is about 5/16". That's right, we end up with slop of about 25% of the shaft diameter. For $40, it does get the job done (mostly), but for fine grinds, this grinder falls flat. I currently use tape to expand the shaft diameter as close as I can to 5/16", but the tape wears out and it's a pain to have to replace it all the time. I've been looking into more permanent mods, but ultimately will probably upgrade to a more precisely engineered grinder.
customer_reviews.author: Steven

customer_reviews.title: Started as a good grinder
customer_reviews.text: This ground very well and evenly at first but as time wore on it became less and less even because the burr somehow became off center. This was only used for coffee and nothing crazy, so I am not sure how this happened. FYI for those considering this grinder.
customer_reviews.author: Jonathan

customer_reviews.title: Great travel grinder
customer_reviews.text: This is exactly what I was needing. I keep this in my backpack and use it at work and when we travel. I love freshly ground coffee, never pre-grind my beans. I have a Bonavita at work, so instead of bringing a noisy electric grinder to the office, I grind my beans from my desk with this. It has allowed me to have great coffee even when I’m not at home.
customer_reviews.author: Keith G.

customer_reviews.title: Good for beginners
customer_reviews.text: For the price I expect a bit more since this is more expensive than a lot of the hand grinders. The consistency is very good for fine grinds, but once you get corser it becomes various in sizes. I think it’s because of the structure of the conical blade, when you grind they kind of wobble around so the gap between the blades are changing. Also the girth of this thing makes it a bit hard to grab when grinding
customer_reviews.author: AmazonUser021

customer_reviews.title: I was pleased with the amount of time it took to grind ...
customer_reviews.text: Works exactly as I had hoped.Does not take forever to finish a grind and filling the hopper produces enough ground coffee for a whole pot (for me, a very strong 32oz french press). On the topic of how long a grind takes, fast is not the point. I was pleased with the amount of time it took to grind a full hopper, but if you are concerned about time you are probably better suited for a Keurig than hand ground coffee.
customer_reviews.author: Chace Cade

customer_reviews.title: Might not fit all hands
customer_reviews.text: I bought this because a barista at a coffee shop told me it was the best. I wish I would have found it in person to try before buying it online because it just doesn’t fit my hands. I have relatively long fingers for a female and I still can’t get a comfortable grip around it. The base is too wide and short and it hurts to hold and grind beans for awhile without switching hands. That being said it does a great, consistent job at grinding. Hario Skerton Ceramic Coffee Hand Grinder
customer_reviews.author: AmazonCustomer4681

customer_reviews.title: Good coffee grinder
customer_reviews.text: I use this to grind coffee almost every morning. It's pretty simple to use, but does have a learning curb on where you need to adjust for particular grinds of coffee. I will say this more consistent than most electric grinders.
customer_reviews.author: Chris Allen

customer_reviews.title: Simple, durable.
customer_reviews.text: I have ground thousands of cups of coffee through this little machine. It's great, durable, and very easy to clean. Took a few tries to get the grind right, but a few years later, it's still like new. I've also found that its great for grinding spices like cloves, dried peppers, anise, etc. So no, it's not electric, it's not fast, but yes - it is simple, easy to use, and a prime tool for developing patience. If you have a lot to grind, you can actually remove the handle and attach the grinder to your cordless drill; this probably voids the warranty, but whatever. Oh, and I've dropped it repeatedly to no ill effect.
customer_reviews.author: Jonathan

customer_reviews.title: Lost locking plate
customer_reviews.text: I bought this grinder to replace an older model that I gave to a friend in need. While the pieces are well made and of solid construction, I find myself missing the older model. The beans have a tendency to come out of the flexible lid, awkward to hold and the grind is difficult to adjust. To find the right setting for french press vs pour over, is cumbersome and frustrating. All that aside, my main problem now is that the little locking plate that sets the grind has gone missing. Its the metal piece with teeth that hold the grind at the chosen setting. Can I purchase this piece?
customer_reviews.author: Sheri D. Ness

customer_reviews.title: Burr is chipped upon arrival
customer_reviews.text: The ceramic burr already has several small chips and dents in it upon arrival. For a product from a reputable brand, this was very disappointing. As other reviewers pointed out, the silicon base is very slippery and doesn't provide a stable foundation when grinding, so i have to grip the middle part with my non-grinding hand. This gets very tiring for anything beyond a single serving amount of beans. I imagine that people with smaller hands would also find it difficult to comfortably hold.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Makes the best coffee I can get
customer_reviews.text: Making espresso with this grinder takes some effort but it is totally worth it for me. If you just want an ok cup of coffee in 60 seconds get a Keurig. But if you want exquisite flavor and can slow down mentally to feel the beans being crunched between the ceramic burrs then you will be rewarded with the aroma and the positively meditative state that results.
customer_reviews.author: Wambozi

customer_reviews.title: 4-5 years of use: Much slower to grind than Hario “mini-slim”
customer_reviews.text: I’ve had this grinder for almost 5 years. Only in the last year has it become unbearably slow to grind - I’m assuming because the ceramic grinder is wearing out. I’ve also had the Hario “Mini-slim” for 4 years and that grinds much faster than the Skerton (and still grinds a coffee’s worth of beans in 2 minutes). I’ll be buying another “mini-slim” instead of another Skerton.
customer_reviews.author: Danielle Crain

customer_reviews.title: Much better grind that powered blades
customer_reviews.text: Great grinder. It takes a while to get the nut properly adjusted to your favorite grind -- a very small adjustment can make quite a difference in the resulting grind. But once you get it dialed in to your liking (and you can always just re-grind stuff that came out too coarse), it performs great, and it is surprising how fast the beans grind even on fine settings. While at first I thought it was taking too long at about 10 minutes (for the full capacity), my technique must be getting better as it is significantly less now.
customer_reviews.author: J. Chandler

customer_reviews.title: Perfect grinder
customer_reviews.text: Perfect for single serve coffee, i use this for my morning coffee along with my aeropress coffee maker, its very easy to use, and very easy to clean, the structure and mechanism is very high quality, been using this religiously since the day i bought it for twice a day, i even pack it with me when i travel, i would say this is a very solid manual grinder and anyone who is looking at this should not hesitate to buy it
customer_reviews.author: SFOD

customer_reviews.title: Works exactly as it should
customer_reviews.text: I ordered the skerton hand grinder because I was looking for something that could ensure a consistent even grind for my V60. The skerton does exactly that. The adjustment of the grind is easy to do and very precise. I'm not mechanically inclined but I found it very easy to disassemble to clean or adjust. I will say it takes a little bit longer than I expected but this is my first foray into hand grinding. If you were to get this quality of a grind from an electric grinder you would need to pay 3-4x more.
customer_reviews.author: Sam Slovisky

customer_reviews.title: Not a Fake
customer_reviews.text: Genuine Hario grinder (thanks to notes from other reviewers I could tell). It is surprisingly quiet and even my kids (5 & 7) were able to help grind while I held the base. The grind is fairly even on finer settings but there is some variability on more coarse grinds. The quality of material is excellent.
customer_reviews.author: HeavyDiaper

customer_reviews.title: Prepare for tastier coffee
customer_reviews.text: My boyfriend noticed that the coffee tasted especially good when I started using the Hario (he did not know I'd gotten it). I have heard that's the effect of burr grinders but didn't realize it would be so dramatic. I always use a french press so I'm doing a coarse grind, and while it does come out a bit uneven, I don't think that it adversely affects flavor. If it bothers you just run the beans through twice to catch the large bits that slipped through the first time. The only annoying thing about it is that the top nut tends to loosen while grinding.
customer_reviews.author: Starling

customer_reviews.title: Happy Customer
customer_reviews.text: Reviews were very mixed for this but I decided to give it a try. I love it! Grinds my espresso very fine, but it can be adjusted for a coarser grind. I don't understand why people complain about how long grinding takes... I can grind espresso (smallest grind) within 5 minutes. No, it's not instant like an electric grinder (duh) but it does a much better job of preserving the integrity of the beans. My espresso comes out with beautiful crema. Very happy I purchased this!
customer_reviews.author: Bia

customer_reviews.title: Good grinder
customer_reviews.text: Works well; the 1/4 cup (20 grams) of beans I grind a little finer than Starbucks grinds their bagged coffee (one notch finer than the Hario was set as delivered) takes about 200 turns, just over two minutes - less time than boiling the water. After a couple of month's use, there's been no change in the grind quality, so no wear evident yet. The nut tends to loosen with use, which some reviewers have reported could damage the interface between the shaft and handle, so I added a drop of Loctite Blue to keep it from backing off, but still removable by hand.
customer_reviews.author: Wordsworth

customer_reviews.title: Inconsistent Grind
customer_reviews.text: When grinding, the burr grinder loosened to the point where you could no longer grind the beans. I had to re-tighten it every 3 minutes or so. For the same reasons, the grind was inconsistent and full beans would filter through. This product is too expensive to be so flimsy. Perhaps this was a fluke, and I received a defective item. But I wouldn't take a chance again.
customer_reviews.author: ConsumerMan

customer_reviews.title: Amazing for the prices. This will change your coffee experience if you usually drink pre-ground coffee.
customer_reviews.text: This is one of the best kitchen tools I've ever bought. My wife loves coffee, and anything I grind with this she far prefers over the pre-ground stuff. Buy any old beans -- you don't need anything fancy. Keep them in the freezer and grind them per-use. The only thing I don't like about it is that, while it's adjustable (you can grind coffee, spices, salt, etc.), there are no markings or other ways to remember what setting like liked for a specific grind. You can just get used to a certain number of turns when tightening it, and that's fine, but I like precision. However, I can't really complain for the price compared to other burr grinders.
customer_reviews.author: Shawn Milochik

customer_reviews.title: This is a great grinder that you can use anywhere
customer_reviews.text: This is a great grinder that you can use anywhere, since it doesn't require electricity. Adjustments to the fineness can be a little tricky. There are no indicators to guide you as to what is fine, medium and coarse. Because of that, you can do outrageous things like grind a bean into four or five pieces. I really like that the grounds container is made of glass. Gives it a bit more of a hefty feel, and grounds won't stick to it like in other grinders. I'd recommend this to someone who wants a grinder to use while outdoors, or someone who doesn't make coffee all that much.
customer_reviews.author: Brandon P

customer_reviews.title: Takes forever to grind a usable amount of coffee
customer_reviews.text: I got this due to numerous online recommendations and I am extraordinarily disappointed. Mostly because it takes forever to grind a usable amount of coffee. Also changing the grind level takes too long and is prone to imprecision as there is no "setting" just twist this until it looks about right. At which point you have to reassemble it and see if you got the grind right. This is far too much of a hassle to use and I can't imagine anyone who drinks more than half a weak cup of coffee a day being satisfied with it.
customer_reviews.author: Rupreckt

customer_reviews.title: Great grinder for a great price.
customer_reviews.text: I use this for spices it cleans very well to avoid cross contamination. I replaced the handle with a nut and use a power drill. Works great and is a ton cheaper than an equally good electric Burr grinder.
customer_reviews.author: D. Grunewald

customer_reviews.title: It's about freshness
customer_reviews.text: Buying freshly roasted coffee and grinding it for every cup makes big difference in taste, especially using pour-over.. Unless you can afford one of the high six-figure models with replaceable ceramic burrs, I'd go for this manual grinder. In the time it takes water to boil you can grind one cup. It can enhance enjoyment to know that you've prepared your coffee without the aid of a bulky plastic housing and the electric grid. Almost nothing to go wrong.
customer_reviews.author: Edward Tenner

customer_reviews.title: Hipster grind
customer_reviews.text: It works and is cheeper by far than all the other grinders on the market. It does need a little fine tuning to get the proper size grains to get ground. Otherwise good. I did give it 4 stars because it takes forever to grind. We are becoming coffee aficionados at work and brew everything 55 grams / liter in the french press. I swear those 55 grams of coffee take a good 3 minutes of continuous grinding to make it though. You will look and feel like a hipster with this product if you use it at work.
customer_reviews.author: Brian Schouten

customer_reviews.title: Used this for months, A+ manual grinder
customer_reviews.text: I was looking for a manual grinder, and after months of using it, I still highly recommend this. Can adjust the coarseness of the grind. Easy to clean. Satisfying to use.
customer_reviews.author: J.Tenneyson

customer_reviews.title: Arm workout!
customer_reviews.text: I like it. If you have a disability in you hand or arm, there might be a problem. I use it daily. Takes a little trial and error to find a grind size that you like but once you have it set, then you dont have to adjust it again. The only complaint I have is that the handle likes to come loose during use. I took a pair of pliers and tightened the knurled knob so that it would not loosen.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Perfect For Moka and Espresso
customer_reviews.text: Great for finer grinds suitable for moka pot and espresso. Not consistent enough for French press without adding the lower bearing upgrade (available through a third party). For coarse grinds suitable for French press, the inner burr wobbles due to the lack of lower shaft support and creates inconsistent grind quality.
customer_reviews.author: Jamie

customer_reviews.title: We enjoyed the grinder before it broke :(
customer_reviews.text: This was our first experience with a hand grinder after using an electric blade grinder for years. We immediately noticed an improvement in flavor from the coffee beans we had been using. It does take a few minutes to hand grind the coffee each morning using the Hario coffee mill, but it has been well worth the effort. Sadly, our Hario broke within the first 40 days of use. I noticed a small metal part on the kitchen counter, and the next morning the unit's grinding system wouldn't remain tight. The product broke a few days outside of the 30-day return window. :(
customer_reviews.author: Richard F. Law

customer_reviews.title: Gets the job done on a budget.
customer_reviews.text: There's not a lot to say. It works great. I was using a grinder that was more like a blender. All the grounds were different sizes. This hand grinder makes almost identical sized grounds. Tastes better less silt in my coffee. I use it for a French press. And it takes a minute to hand grind the beans. I'm done grinding before the waters hot. It's perfect for singles or couples, but if you want to grind more than that every morning you'll want a electric one. I wouldn't want to hand grind coffee for a twelve cup drip maker every morning. But if you looking for perfect coffee on a budget this is it.
customer_reviews.author: KYLE

customer_reviews.title: this wasn't overly easy to use and the grinding mill gears weren't always ...
customer_reviews.text: It's a lot of hard work to grind your own coffee. I used this out at camp and appreciated having free coffee. That said, this wasn't overly easy to use and the grinding mill gears weren't always perfectly lined up. It worked for my needs, but if I needed to use it daily, I would have invested in an electric version or something a bit easier to work with.
customer_reviews.author: major_critic.deal_lover

customer_reviews.title: Great little grinder
customer_reviews.text: I like how easy it is to use, setting the grinding level, with the silicone base ease of grinding, simple cleaning and that they furnish a second container for storage makes it very convenient.
customer_reviews.author: Big D&GD

customer_reviews.title: Works great, have for 6+ years, no issues.
customer_reviews.text: Had this in Afghanistan on 2014 with a French Press thermos. Works great.
customer_reviews.author: MMC...

customer_reviews.title: Inconsistent grind!
customer_reviews.text: Did not produce a consistent grind in any sense...tried to get it to grind to the consistency of sand, which is recommended for pour over methods....but at every setting I would get grounds of all sizes, from big chunks which would serve to clog the burrs, to powdery dust that made the used grounds look like clay mud. Do not purchase! Go with a different hand grinder, or an electric.
customer_reviews.author: E. Mumbert

customer_reviews.title: Hario Grinder!
customer_reviews.text: I love this grinder! I received mine from Amazon.com LLC and it was the product with all parts and instructions.The instructions were in English and Japanese. I use mine to make grinds for cold brewed ice coffee.There was a little fumbling on my part to get a good understanding of the grind size. Trial and error will need to be done to get your preferred grind and switching the mechanism mid-trail is not super easy. Other then that, I sit down, watch a bit of tv or even read a book, and grind away. It's a great workout. The anti-slip gripper on the bottom keeps it stable.
customer_reviews.author: wickedwolf

customer_reviews.title: Not for course grinding
customer_reviews.text: When I received the grinder i noticed that the lower shaft portion was totally unsupported. Thus when you would try to course grind the result would be uneven chunks and smalls. For my use with a French press this does not satisfy my needs. I have heard that there is a kit that you can buy to support the lower shaft from  . They also sell hand grinders that are build like a rock, I would recommend buying the Lideo 2 if you have the funds to do so. I am looking into purchasing one in the future.
customer_reviews.author: Christopher Miller

customer_reviews.title: Perfect for the right person
customer_reviews.text: I use this to make a loose grind for a french press every day, and it works as advertised. It is also quiet. The grind adjustment is set by unscrewing the handle, lifting off a metal key and resetting it to lock the grinder at a different level. Because there is no dial it is done by trial and error. For that reason I would only recommend this for those who want to set it and forget it - going back and forth between grinds would drive you crazy. It takes 25 turns per tablespoon of coffee beans, so it works well for 1 - 2 cups. If you're brewing more, get an electric grinder.
customer_reviews.author: William T. Baldwin

customer_reviews.title: Excellent hand-cranked coffee grinder
customer_reviews.text: As others have noted, the crank has a tendency to get a little loose when grinding. I added a 6mm lock washer between the crank and the screw cap and tightened it down with pliers to prevent the screw cap from working loose, and that's solved the problem. I also noticed that the ceramic grinding wheel is not perfectly level, and one side is about 1/8" higher than the opposite side. In practice, this has not caused a noticeable problem.
customer_reviews.author: Matthew Newby

customer_reviews.title: Good quality grind. Poor quality grinder.
customer_reviews.text: The grounds come out relatively uniform and it is easy enough to adjust the coarseness. The quality of the grinder itself isn't great (I owned the plus model). While using the grinder the nut that held the handle on would constantly come loose and would need to be re-tightened. This might not be an issue with the pro model because there is no nut at all. I decided to return it.
customer_reviews.author: Michael R.

customer_reviews.title: Consistent manual grinder
customer_reviews.text: Excellent, consistent grind. Easy to clean and relatively easy to adjust the size of the grind, plus it’s cheap. It can get to be a bit of a workout when making finer grinds, otherwise an excellent product.
customer_reviews.author: Bizzy

customer_reviews.title: Good grinder, a bit fiddly
customer_reviews.text: Changing the grind setting it a little frustrating. Sometimes there is a click like the adjustment is stepped, other times it spins freely. It leaves you guessing how much you actually adjusted your fine/coarseness. The rubber base does not adhere to the glass very well. When grinding on the counter it tends to roll in the rubber base. If you have small hands it might be hard to hold.
customer_reviews.author: Don Bergstrom

customer_reviews.title: This is a good backup grinder (when electricity is out
customer_reviews.text: Legit! This is a good backup grinder (when electricity is out, or when I'm travelling/camping), or a great grinder for getting your pre-caffeinated blood flowing in the morning with a mild arm workout. I use it for the daily pour-over. That style calls for a medium grind, so I am not as worried about the apparent design flaw ("wobble") many report which requires some kind of fix or retrofit in order to make super-fine grinds (i.e. espresso).
customer_reviews.author: Austin Durant

customer_reviews.title: High quality, effective, consistent grinder
customer_reviews.text: Very consistent grind, grinds better tasting coffee, works great! Perfect for pour-over and a good choice for espresso. It's okay for French Press, but the grind slightly less consistent but that is the nature of most grinders - not a big deal. I find that taking the rubber base off helps to keep it upright while grinding, otherwise it slides to one side and stays lopsided. But that might just be me...
customer_reviews.author: Lainey Lee

customer_reviews.title: Excellent build quality, down to every little part
customer_reviews.text: Excellent build quality, down to every little part. Every detail of this manual grinder is well-made, even the packaging. A big plus for me is that it can be near-completely disassembled (for cleanup/maintenance, though it's unnecessary). Though be warned, manual grinding is a tedious task which takes more than a few minutes to make enough coffee ground for a strong espresso. And the large diameter neck tires out even larger-than-average hands. A tip: brace it/hold it against your inner thigh as you grind; makes the task less tiresome.
customer_reviews.author: Mike

customer_reviews.title: Excellent product at a very fair price
customer_reviews.text: If you are looking for a mill that provides a consistent fine to extra fine grind, this certainly will fit the bill. Clearly made to exacting standards out of first quality materials, I cannot imagine a better deal for the price. It is capable of grinding coffee for an espresso machine on par in terms of quality to what I obtain using my Rancilio Rocky Doserless Coffee Grinder. Of course you must be disposed to spend some time grinding away, but this is to be expected with a manual coffee mill. As another reviewer has noted, using a pressure washer to keep the grinding arm firmly in place will provide notable improvement. Highly recommended.
customer_reviews.author: Manuel Antonio Arce Arenales

customer_reviews.title: the Hario is of much better use for making larger pots
customer_reviews.text: I have both the Javapresse and this, and use both (one is set for AeroPress, the other for french press. Clearly, the Hario is of much better use for making larger pots...I don't know why they don't make one that has bearings to hold the burr steady...I would pay s few dollars more...BTW, stay away from the aftermarket "bearing" ..they don;t really work.
customer_reviews.author: Drworry

customer_reviews.title: Wonderful grinder, especially after modification
customer_reviews.text: I got this grinder for espresso, and it really does the trick, but the fine grind that espresso requires was taking forever on the hand crank. So I went down to the hardware store and got a Qwikbore Spade Drill Extension and fit it into my handheld electric screwdriver, so no more hand crank.... it works great! The extension bit just in case anyone needs one is similar to amazon item #B00BRL6WXK, although the one I got is 4" long, instead of 6"... 4" is better, just can't seem to find that on amazon. Anyway, I'm very pleased with the product, and enjoying a hot cup of espresso right now!!! :)
customer_reviews.author: Gary Stevens

product_meta.title: Hario Ceramic Coffee Mill - "Skerton Plus"
product_meta.description: Style Name:Skerton PlusIn Japanese, HARIO means "The King of Glass". Since its founding in 1921, this Japanese company has been manufacturing glassware of the highest quality for general consumers and for industrial uses. This hand grinder has been designed by Hario to provide coffee lovers with an inexpensive means to have freshly-ground coffee, even while traveling with a light load.
